column1: 160,https://macdailynews.com/2023/05/02/apple-and-alphabet-join-forces-to-fight-unwanted-airtag-tracking/,8ebeeb2ddcc74d869a7018cc634727c4,us,en,2023-05-02T17:11:26+00:00,Apple and Alphabet join forces to fight unwanted AirTag tracking,Apple and Google have jointly submitted a proposed industry specification to help combat the misuse of Bluetooth location-tracking devices for unwanted tracking. The first-of-its-kind specification will allow Bluetooth location tracking devices to be compatible with unauthorized tracking detection and alerts across iOS and Android platforms. Samsung
column2: Tile
column3: Chipolo
column4: eufy Security
column5: and Pebblebee have expressed support for the draft specification. The specification has been submitted as an Internet-Draft via the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF)
column6: a leading standards development organization. Interested parties are invited and encouraged to review and comment over the next three months. Apple and Google will partner to address feedback
column7: and will release a production implementation of the specification by the end of 2023.,Apple and Google said on Tuesday they were working together to curb unwanted tracking of people by Bluetooth devices such as AirTags used…,"Apple and Alphabet subsidiary Google said on Tuesday they were working together to curb unwanted tracking of people by Bluetooth devices such as AirTags used for finding lost items.

column1: Location-tracking devices help users find personal items like their keys
column2: purse
column3: luggage
column4: and more through crowdsourced finding networks. However
column5: they can also be misused for unwanted tracking of individuals.

column1: Today Apple and Google jointly submitted a proposed industry specification to help combat the misuse of Bluetooth location-tracking devices for unwanted tracking. The first-of-its-kind specification will allow Bluetooth location-tracking devices to be compatible with unauthorized tracking detection and alerts across iOS and Android platforms. Samsung
column2: Tile
column3: Chipolo
column4: eufy Security
column5: and Pebblebee have expressed support for the draft specification
column6: which offers best practices and instructions for manufacturers
column7: should they choose to build these capabilities into their products.

column1: “Apple launched AirTag to give users the peace of mind knowing where to find their most important items
column2: ” said Ron Huang
column3: Apple’s vice president of Sensing and Connectivity. “We built AirTag and the Find My network with a set of proactive features to discourage unwanted tracking — a first in the industry — and we continue to make improvements to help ensure the technology is being used as intended. This new industry specification builds upon the AirTag protections
column4: and through collaboration with Google results in a critical step forward to help combat unwanted tracking across iOS and Android.”

column1: “Bluetooth trackers have created tremendous user benefits
column2: but they also bring the potential of unwanted tracking
column3: which requires industrywide action to solve
column4: ” said Dave Burke
column5: Google’s vice president of Engineering for Android. “Android has an unwavering commitment to protecting users
column6: and will continue to develop strong safeguards and collaborate with the industry to help combat the misuse of Bluetooth tracking devices.”

column1: In addition to incorporating feedback from device manufacturers
column2: input from various safety and advocacy groups has been integrated into the development of the specification.

column1: “The National Network to End Domestic Violence has been advocating for universal standards to protect survivors — and all people — from the misuse of Bluetooth tracking devices. This collaboration and the resulting standards are a significant step forward. NNEDV is encouraged by this progress
column2: ” said Erica Olsen
column3: the National Network to End Domestic Violence’s senior director of its Safety Net Project. “These new standards will minimize opportunities for abuse of this technology and decrease the burden on survivors in detecting unwanted trackers. We are grateful for these efforts and look forward to continuing to work together to address unwanted tracking and misuse.”

column1: “Today’s release of a draft specification is a welcome step to confront harmful misuses of Bluetooth location trackers
column2: ” said Alexandra Reeve Givens
column3: the Center for Democracy & Technology’s president and CEO. “CDT continues to focus on ways to make these devices more detectable and reduce the likelihood that they will be used to track people. A key element to reducing misuse is a universal
column4: OS-level solution that is able to detect trackers made by different companies on the variety of smartphones that people use every day. We commend Apple and Google for their partnership and dedication to developing a uniform solution to improve detectability. We look forward to the specification moving through the standardization process and to further engagement on ways to reduce the risk of Bluetooth location trackers being misused.”

column1: MacDailyNews Note: The specification has been submitted as an Internet-Draft via the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF)
column2: a leading standards development organization. Interested parties are invited and encouraged to review and comment over the next three months. Following the comment period
column3: Apple and Google will partner to address feedback
column4: and will release a production implementation of the specification for unwanted tracking alerts by the end of 2023 that will then be supported in future versions of iOS and Android.

column1: 163,https://technewsspace.com/apple-dismisses-2-billion-lawsuit-alleging-artificially-slowing-down-iphone/,61bd3cf7c106441293d4393c9f18ab67,us,en,2023-05-02T17:13:33+00:00,Apple Dismisses $2 Billion Lawsuit Alleging Artificially Slowing Down IPhone,Apple is facing lawsuits worth up to $2 billion brought by Justin Gutmann
column2: head of consumer advocacy

column4: intentionally slowing down older iPhones and making their batteries faster by updating the iOS software platform to unload. Apple denies the lawsuit is “unfounded” and denies that its iPhone batteries are defective

column9: Apple asked a London court to block a $2 billion class action lawsuit accusing the company of using inferior batteries
column10: intentionally slowing down older iPhones and making their batteries faster by updating the iOS software platform to unload.

column1: The tech giant is facing lawsuits worth up to $2 billion brought by head of consumer advocacy Justin Gutmann on behalf of iPhone users in the UK. Gutmann’s lawyers alleged in court documents that Apple had hidden battery problems in some phone models and secretly installed a power management tool that limited the smartphone’s performance.
Apple stated in writing that the lawsuit was “unfounded” and vehemently denies that its iPhone batteries were defective
column2: except for a small number of iPhone 6s models for which it offered free battery replacements. The company also reports that a power management update introduced in 2017 to manage old batteries or weak batteries only slowed the iPhone 6’s performance by an average of 10%.

column1: On Tuesday Gutmann appealed to the London Competition Court of Appeal to confirm the case and bring it to trial. His attorney
column2: Philip Moser
column3: cited Apple’s 2020 US Class Action Settlement Agreement and US state regulatory lawsuits over iPhone battery issues as evidence that Apple “didn’t say it never happenedIn 2019
column4: Apple also pledged to be “more open” with iPhone users about battery health before the UK regulator
column5: Moser said.

column1: The company denies misleading its customers about iPhone battery issues
column2: citing a public apology it issued in 2017 that offered affected customers cheaper battery replacements. Apple attorney David Wolfson said the lawsuit actually alleges that “Not all batteries can deliver the required peak performance under all circumstances and at all times‘
column3: which is typical of all battery-powered devices.",technewsspace.com,0.020144213,0.8811584,0.09869744,,[],False,,0

column1: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) — Apple and Google are teaming up to thwart unwanted tracking through Bluetooth devices that were created to help people find lost keys
column2: keep tabs on luggage or to locate other things that have a tendency to be misplaced or lost.

column1: The two companies behind the iPhone and the software that powers Android phones on Tuesday submitted a proposal to set standards for combatting secret surveillance on Apple’s AirTag trackers and similar gadgets. The concept also has the backing of Samsung
column2: which sells the most Android smartphones worldwide
column3: as well as tracking products similar to the AirTag such as Tile
column4: Chipolo
column5: and Pebblebee.

column1: The $30 AirTag has become a popular item since its 2021 release
column2: helping users pinpoint the locations of a wide variety of lost property. But stalkers have also deployed AirTags and similar products to shadow former love interests and other people who don’t realize they are being tracked.

column1: “Bluetooth trackers have created tremendous user benefits
column2: but they also bring the potential of unwanted tracking
column3: which requires industrywide action to solve
column4: ” said Dave Burke
column5: Google’s vice president of Engineering for Android.

column1: Apple and AirTag hope to have a plan in place by the end of this year to thwart stealth tracking. The solution would be distributed through software updates to iPhones and Android phones.
Erica Olsen
column2: the senior director of National Network to End Domestic Violence’s Safety Net Project
column3: applauded the effort to set an industry standard that she believes will help protect survivors of abusive relationships and other people that have been targets of stealth technology. “These new standards will minimize opportunities for abuse of this technology and decrease the burden on survivors in detecting unwanted trackers
column4: ” Olsen said.

column8: keep tabs on luggage or to locate other,"SAN FRANCISCO (AP) — Apple and Google are teaming up to thwart unwanted tracking through Bluetooth devices that were created to help people find lost keys
column9: keep tabs on luggage or to locate other things that have a tendency to be misplaced or lost.

column1: The two companies behind the iPhone and the software that powers Android phones on Tuesday submitted a proposal to set standards for combatting secret surveillance on Apple's AirTag trackers and similar gadgets. The concept also has the backing of Samsung
column2: which sells the most Android smartphones worldwide
column3: as well as tracking products similar to the AirTag such as Tile
column4: Chipolo
column5: and Pebblebee.

column1: The $30 AirTag has become a popular item since its 2021 release
column2: helping users pinpoint the locations of a wide variety of lost property. But stalkers have also deployed AirTags and similar products to shadow former love interests and other people who don’t realize they are being tracked.

column1: “Bluetooth trackers have created tremendous user benefits
column2: but they also bring the potential of unwanted tracking
column3: which requires industrywide action to solve
column4: ” said Dave Burke
column5: Google’s vice president of Engineering for Android.

column1: Apple and AirTag hope to have a plan in place by the end of this year to thwart stealth tracking. The solution would be distributed through software updates to iPhones and Android phones.
Erica Olsen
column2: the senior director of National Network to End Domestic Violence’s Safety Net Project
column3: applauded the effort to set an industry standard that she believes will help protect survivors of abusive relationships and other people that have been targets of stealth technology. “These new standards will minimize opportunities for abuse of this technology and decrease the burden on survivors in detecting unwanted trackers

column1: Official Collapse of First Republic Bank
Well
column2: we have one less thing to worry about.

column1: After two months of teetering
column2: regulators took over First Republic Bank on Sunday and its assets have been sold to JPMorgan Chase.

column1: First Republic’s demise amounts to the second-largest bank failure in U.S. history. It surpasses Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank and ranks just behind the 2008 failure of Washington Mutual.
We can put a pin in the longer story — whether the JPMorgan takeover was “fair
column2: ” or if this was another case of a large
column3: politically-connected bank getting a sweetheart deal. And we can similarly hold on to this question: if it’s wise to allow any single bank to become as powerful as JPMorgan is today.

column1: For our immediate purposes
column2: the sale is a good thing. It removes the lingering threat (at least for now) of a disorderly failure that could have led to regional banks falling like dominos. JPMorgan’s actions provided a very useful backstop.

column1: Banks have been retrenching for months. Consumers gorged themselves on cheap credit in 2021 and early 2022
column2: and the banks were happy to oblige. But as interest rates rose and lending standards got stricter
column3: credit card and other revolving consumer loans started to go into decline in October last year.

column1: Commercial loans are larger and tend to have a more cumbersome review process. Yet despite this
column2: the drop-off in commercial lending has increased.

column1: The amount lent in commercial and industrial loans has been in freefall since last June. And it’s worth noting that this data only goes through March. Any fallout from the failures of Silicon Valley Bank
column2: Signature Bank and First Republic Bank wouldn’t be showing up in the data yet.

column1: It’s important to remember that the Federal Reserve doesn’t actually “print” money
column2: even though we often refer to their stimulative activities as money printing.

column1: Depending on how exactly you measure money
column2: only 10% to 20% of cash takes the form of physical bills and coins. Most dollars are blips on a screen that are lent into circulation.

column1: So less lending by the banks means less money floating around in the economy
column2: and ultimately
column3: means less growth.

column1: Does this mean we’re in for a recession?
The Conference Board
column2: who produces the Leading Indicators Index
column3: is currently assigning a 99% probability of a recession over the next 12 months.

column1: A recession is not the end of the world. We need a recession every now and then to reset the clock
column2: so to speak.

column1: Recessions lower inflation and weed out struggling businesses
column2: which gives a longer runway for strong businesses to grow. And it’s during hard times that new and exciting innovations get put to work.

column1: I expect the next recession to turbocharge some of the trends that Ian has already been writing about for months
column2: or even years now
column3: including automation and artificial intelligence.

column1: What better time to put cost-cutting technology to work than when your back is to the wall.",banyanhill.com,0.15221465,0.012778353,0.835007,Alexandra Gomez,[],False,,0

column1: Although the update is a bit late to the party

column3: which Apple introduced in late 2020. Competitor Ableton Live didn’t launch M1 support until February 2022
column4: and even Apple’s Logic Pro didn’t run natively on the company’s chipset until a year after the first M1 Macs’ arrival.

column1: Reason 12.6 also includes a new offline mode

column4: the software will continue working offline without requiring extra third-party software.

column3: the company offers users running old versions an extra incentive to update by offering 40 percent off Reason 12 upgrades through May 8th when purchasing from the developer’s website.

column7: applauded the effort to set an industry standard that will help protect survivors of abusive relationships and other people that have been targets of stealth technology.,Apple and Google are teaming up to thwart unwanted tracking through Bluetooth devices that were created to help people find lost keys
column8: keep tabs on luggage or to locate other,"SAN FRANCISCO (AP) — Apple and Google are teaming up to thwart unwanted tracking through Bluetooth devices that were created to help people find lost keys
column9: keep tabs on luggage or to locate other things that have a tendency to be misplaced or lost.

column1: The two companies behind the iPhone and the software that powers Android phones on Tuesday submitted a proposal to set standards for combatting secret surveillance on Apple's AirTag trackers and similar gadgets. The concept also has the backing of Samsung
column2: which sells the most Android smartphones worldwide
column3: as well as tracking products similar to the AirTag such as Tile
column4: Chipolo
column5: and Pebblebee.

column1: The $30 AirTag has become a popular item since its 2021 release
column2: helping users pinpoint the locations of a wide variety of lost property. But stalkers have also deployed AirTags and similar products to shadow former love interests and other people who don’t realize they are being tracked.

column1: “Bluetooth trackers have created tremendous user benefits
column2: but they also bring the potential of unwanted tracking
column3: which requires industrywide action to solve
column4: ” said Dave Burke
column5: Google’s vice president of Engineering for Android.

column1: Apple and AirTag hope to have a plan in place by the end of this year to thwart stealth tracking. The solution would be distributed through software updates to iPhones and Android phones.
Erica Olsen
column2: the senior director of National Network to End Domestic Violence’s Safety Net Project
column3: applauded the effort to set an industry standard that she believes will help protect survivors of abusive relationships and other people that have been targets of stealth technology. “These new standards will minimize opportunities for abuse of this technology and decrease the burden on survivors in detecting unwanted trackers

column2: Google Develop Specification to Address Unwanted Bluetooth Tracking,Apple and Google have developed a draft specification to enable product manufacturers to detect and alert users when small devices such as AirTags are tracking their movements surreptitiously. The specification
column3: in the hands of the IETF
column4: is the first industry-led effort to address the problem of unwanted Bluetooth trackers. It defines a set of recommendations and requirements for the ways that manufacturers should design their devices to behave both when they are in proximity to their owner and when they’re separated from the owner’s device. The key requirement is for trackers to have the ability to determine when they have been separated from their device for a set period of time and then play a sound to alert non-owners that the tracker is moving with them. The draft specification will now work its way through the process of potentially becoming an IETF Internet standard
column5: and manufacturers can adopt any of the best practices and recommendations they want at any point.,Apple and Google have submitted a draft IETF specification to alert users when they are being tracked by Bluetooth accessories such as AirTags.,"Apple and Google have developed a draft framework to enable product manufacturers to detect and alert users when small devices such as AirTags are tracking their movements surreptitiously. The specification
column6: which is in the hands of the IETF
column7: is the first industry-led effort to address the problem of unwanted Bluetooth trackers.

column1: Small location-enabled Bluetooth devices such as AirTags
column2: Tile
column3: Pebblebee
column4: and others offer users the ability to track items such as keys
column5: wallets
column6: luggage
column7: or pretty much anything they want. The trackers are usually quite small and are relatively inexpensive
column8: so they have become very popular among both legitimate users as well as bad actors who want to track people or physical objects for malicious purposes. Privacy advocates and groups that work with domestic abuse victims have warned about the ways in which criminals can abuse these trackers to surveil people without their knowledge.

column1: The new specification defines a set of recommendations and requirements for the ways that manufacturers should design their devices to behave both when they’re in proximity to their owner and when they’re separated from the owner. The key requirement is for trackers to have the ability to determine when they’ve been separated from the owner’s device for a set period of time and then play a sound to alert non-owners that the tracker is moving with them. The trackers also must have a mechanism to allow non-owners to find them.
“Bluetooth trackers have created tremendous user benefits but also bring the potential of unwanted tracking
column2: which requires industry-wide action to solve
column3: ” said Dave Burke
column4: vice president of engineering for Android at Google.

column1: Among the other components of the draft specification is a pairing registry that would store information about the owner of a specific accessory at the time that it’s paired with a device. That data would include the email address and phone number of the owner
column2: and obfuscated data would be available to the platform provider
column3: for example Apple.

column1: The companies submitted the draft specification to the Internet Engineering Task Force on Tuesday and it will now work its way through the process of potentially becoming an IETF Internet standard. That process can take years
column2: but manufacturers can adopt any of the best practices and recommendations they want at any point.

column1: “Formalizing a set of best practices for manufacturers will allow for scalable compatibility with unwanted tracking detection technologies on various smartphone platforms and improve privacy and security for individuals
column2: ” the draft says.

column1: “Unwanted tracking detection can both detect and alert individuals that a location tracker separated from the owner's device is traveling with them
column2: as well as provide means to find and disable the tracker.”

column1: Lawmakers have held many hearings about online tracking and surveillance in the last few years
column2: but those have focused almost exclusively on the ways that platform providers and ad tech companies track people across the web. The individualized
column3: targeted surveillance that small Bluetooth-enabled trackers can allow is a different story altogether and not one that’s easily addressed by regulations or legislation. Which is why industry initiatives such as this draft specification are vital.

column1: “A key element to reducing misuse is a universal
column2: OS-level solution that is able to detect trackers made by different companies on the variety of smartphones that people use every day
column3: ” said Alexandra Reeve Givens
column4: president and CEO of the Center for Democracy and Technology.",duo.com,0.058295853,0.029803697,0.91190046,,[],False,,0

column12: ” according to a […],"Apple and Google announced on Tuesday that they will work together to prevent location-tracking devices — such as the AirTag — from being used to track people without their permission.

column1: The tech companies banded together to draft an “industry specification to help combat the misuse of Bluetooth location-tracking devices for unwanted tracking
column2: ” according to a press release.

column1: The specification will allow the location-tracking devices to be compatible with unauthorized tracking detection and alerts

column1: Samsung
column2: Tile
column3: Chipolo

column5: and Pebblebee have all expressed support for the draft specification

column1: The Apple AirTag is a coin-size device that allows a user to track the whereabouts of their technology in real-time on an iPhone app. However
column2: the device has been utilized for more nefarious reasons
column3: with multiple users reporting that it has been used for stalking since it went on sale in 2021
column4: according to CNBC.

column1: While the AirTag and iPhone app has been set up with proactive features to discourage unwanted tracking
column2: the draft will suggest that Android users will also soon gain the same protections.

column1: “We built AirTag and the Find My network with a set of proactive features to discourage unwanted tracking — a first in the industry — and we continue to make improvements to help ensure the technology is being used as intended
column2: ” Ron Huang
column3: Apple’s vice president of Sensing and Connectivity
column4: said in the press release.

column1: “This new industry specification builds upon the AirTag protections
column2: and through collaboration with Google results in a critical step forward to help combat unwanted tracking across iOS and Android
column3: ” he added.

column1: So
column2: how will this standard work? Well
column3: it would allow Bluetooth-enabled gadgets to be compatible with unauthorized tracking detection and alerts across both iOS and Android ecosystems. They’ve already got the support of Tile
column4: Samsung

column6: Pebblebee
column7: Chipolo

column10: they’ll release a production implement of the specification
column11: which is expected by the end of 2023.

column3: Google and Apple seem to be taking things a step further. This is great news

column16: I like software updates
column17: and I’m not alone—some of us enjoy seeing what new features developers have cooked up. But even though they’re less exciting
column18: I’m an even bigger fan of security updates...and Apple is introducing a new type of security update for iPhones
column19: iPads
column20: and Macs. It’s called Rapid Security Responses.

column1: Rapid Security Responses are Apple’s latest update to their updates. Rather than deliver any new features or major software changes
column2: Rapid Security Responses patch security vulnerabilities that pop up in between regular updates. If Apple or a third-party discover a security issue with Safari
column3: the WebKit framework stack
column4: or critical system libraries across Apple devices
column5: the company can patch the issue and deliver it to users as soon as possible.

column1: The first patch rolled out Monday
column2: May 1
column3: for iOS 16.4.1
column4: iPadOS 16.4.1
column5: and macOS 13.3.1. After running into an issue which prevented the patch from installing
column6: the first Rapid Security Response is installing fine—although Apple isn’t specific about what’s actually in it.

column1: As security-focused as Apple is
column2: its prior approach to patches wasn’t the best. Other operating systems like Android separated their software updates from their security updates. That way
column3: whenever Google would patch a critical security flaw
column4: they could quickly issue it through their security update channel. Apple
column5: on the other hand
column6: usually waited until there was enough of a reason to update everyone’s iPhones
column7: unless the issue was so dangerous they needed to push an update
column8: which would then change the entire OS version. (That’s why we sometimes see weird versions of Apple’s software
column9: like iOS 16.4.1. That’s a version of iOS 16.4 that needed to include security patches before an iOS 16.5 was ready.) The one caveat was Safari
column10: which
column11: on Mac at least
column12: Apple would issue security updates separately for as needed.

column1: To be clear
column2: Rapid Security Responses aren’t for every Apple device. Rather
column3: they’re available starting with iOS 16.4.1
column4: iPadOS 16.4.1
column5: and macOS 13.3.1. If your iPhone
column6: iPad
column7: or Mac isn’t running the latest software
column8: you won’t have the option to install the latest Rapid Security Response
column9: and you’ll need to wait for the next major update to reap the security benefits. That said
column10: if a security vulnerability actively threatens Apple users
column11: chances are the company will expedite the new update.

column1: You can even uninstall security updates in the event something goes wrong. You won’t want to do this unless the update messes with your device
column2: though
column3: since you’ll risk exposing yourself to the security vulnerabilities that the update patches.

column1: iOS Security Response 16.4.1 (a) is Out! - What’s New?

column2: iPad
column3: or Mac

column1: Apple
column2: by default
column3: grants your iPhone
column4: iPad
column5: or Mac permission to install Rapid Security Responses automatically. That’s obviously a good thing
column6: but it isn’t foolproof: Like traditional automatic updates from Apple
column7: Rapid Security Responses might not update right away
column8: even with this setting enabled. If you want to keep your iPhone
column9: iPad
column10: or Mac fully up to date at all times
column11: you’ll want to check for patches regularly.

column1: It’s easy to do
column2: since Rapid Security Responses appear in your device’s Software Updates page. On iOS and iPadOS
column3: that’s under Settings > General > Software Update
column4: while on Mac
column5: that’s System Settings > Software Update. You can install it like any other software update.

column1: The Rapid Security Response shows up with the same version number as the latest iOS
column2: iPadOS
column3: or macOS update
column4: but with an (a) attached to differentiate itself. For example
column5: this latest update shows up on iPhone as iOS 16.4.1 (a).",lifehacker.com,0.036794383,0.10002971,0.8631759,Jake Peterson,[],False,,0

column2: cases of undesired tracking with Bluetooth trackers such as Apple’s AirTags have become known. Apple has taken measures to prevent stalking with AirTags
column3: such as a warning tone when someone else’s AirTag is in the vicinity of another person for a certain period of time.

column1: Potential victims also receive instructions on their iPhone on how to turn off the alien AirTag in their area. However
column2: this anti-stalking protection only works if everyone involved is using an iPhone. However
column3: that is about to change.

column1: “A first in the industry”
“Apple launched AirTag to give users the confidence to find their most important items
column2: ” said Ron Huang
column3: Apple’s vice president of sensing and connectivity. AirTag and the Find My network have been equipped with a number of proactive features to prevent unwanted tracking – an industry first. The company also continues to work on improvements to ensure the technology is used as intended.

column1: “This new industry standard builds on AirTag’s defenses and
column2: in collaboration with Google
column3: is a critical step forward to combat unwanted tracking on iOS and Android
column4: ” said Huang.

column1: “Bluetooth trackers have brought tremendous benefits to users
column2: but they also harbor the potential for unwanted tracking that only cross-industry efforts can solve
column3: ” said Dave Burke
column4: Google’s vice president of engineering for Android. “Android is relentless in protecting users and will continue to develop strong protections and work with the industry to combat Bluetooth tracker abuse.”

column1: Today’s release of a draft specification is a welcome step in addressing the harmful misuse of Bluetooth location devices
column2: said Alexandra Reeve Givens
column3: President and CEO of the Center for Democracy & Technology.

column1: Companies interested in the draft industry standard have three months to review and comment. By the end of 2023

column7: applauded the effort to set an industry standard that she believes will help protect survivors of abusive relationships and other people that have been targets of stealth technology.,Apple and Google submitted a proposal Tuesday to set standards for combatting secret surveillance on Apple's AirTag trackers and similar gadgets.,"SAN FRANCISCO — Apple and Google are teaming up to thwart unwanted tracking through Bluetooth devices that were created to help people find lost keys
column8: keep tabs on luggage or to locate other things that have a tendency to be misplaced or lost.

column1: The two companies behind the iPhone and the software that powers Android phones on Tuesday submitted a proposal to set standards for combatting secret surveillance on Apple's AirTag trackers and similar gadgets. The concept also has the backing of Samsung
column2: which sells the most Android smartphones worldwide
column3: as well as tracking products similar to the AirTag such as Tile
column4: Chipolo
column5: and Pebblebee.

column1: The $30 AirTag has become a popular item since its 2021 release
column2: helping users pinpoint the locations of a wide variety of lost property. But stalkers have also deployed AirTags and similar products to shadow former love interests and other people who don't realize they are being tracked.

column1: Bluetooth trackers have created tremendous user benefits
column2: but they also bring the potential of unwanted tracking
column3: which requires industrywide action to solve
column4: said Dave Burke
column5: Google's vice president of Engineering for Android.

column1: Apple and AirTag hope to have a plan in place by the end of this year to thwart stealth tracking. The solution would be distributed through software updates to iPhones and Android phones.
Erica Olsen
column2: the senior director of National Network to End Domestic Violence's Safety Net Project
column3: applauded the effort to set an industry standard that she believes will help protect survivors of abusive relationships and other people that have been targets of stealth technology. ""These new standards will minimize opportunities for abuse of this technology and decrease the burden on survivors in detecting unwanted trackers
column4: Olsen said.",ksl.com,0.22739556,0.024267605,0.7483368,Deseret Digital Media,[],True,,0

column1: Today Apple and Google jointly submitted a proposed industry specification to help combat the misuse of Bluetooth location-tracking devices for unwanted tracking. The first-of-its-kind specification will allow Bluetooth location-tracking devices to be compatible with unauthorized tracking detection and alerts across iOS and Android platforms. Samsung
column2: Tile

column6: which offers best practices and instructions for manufacturers

column9: it seemed like a typical Tuesday at St. Andrew School in Lakeview. But inside
column10: students and staff came together with eager anticipation to let 6th grade teacher Rachel W…,"CHICAGO — From the outside
column11: it seemed like a typical Tuesday at St. Andrew School in Lakeview. But inside
column12: students and staff came together with eager anticipation to let 6th grade teacher Rachel Werderits in on a big secret.

column1: She’s the recipient of the prestigious Golden Apple Award for Excellence in Teaching.
“Students talked about her riding her bike and running by their houses and writing notes to each of her students in chalk and also problems on the sidewalk
column2: ” said Alan Mather
column3: President of the Golden Apple Foundation. “And so
column4: when they’d get on Zoom
column5: it was like ‘whose house did she visit today?'”

column1: Werderits has taught at St. Andrew for 14 years
column2: and she’s known since the fifth grade that this was her calling.

column1: “I started taking chalk from school and using the back of my bedroom door as a chalkboard and I taught imaginary lessons in my bedroom
column2: ” Werderits said.

column1: And on Tuesday
column2: all her hard work paid off.

column1: “I am very humbled and honored to be recognized
column2: ” Werderits said. “The challenges and the celebrations were able to have in the classroom are very rewarding.”

column1: The Golden Apple Award comes with a $5
column2: 000 check – and Werderits becomes a fellow with the Golden Apple Academy of Educators – who aim to encourage the next generation
column3: hoping to help close the gap in Illinois’ teacher shortage.

column1: “I am very excited to take the baton and I love working with people
column2: I love coaching
column3: ” Werderits said. “So
column4: I’m super excited to be able to mentor wherever I can to develop some more excellent teachers in our system.”",wgntv.com,0.13713202,0.02682221,0.83604574,Jenna Barnes and Eli Ong,"[{'country': 'us', 'state': 'IL', 'county': 'Madison County'}]",False,IL,0
